Graphical abstract Doping B2O3 to an Ag/SiO2 catalyst notably improves its activity as well as its stability for the vapor-phase hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate (DMO) to methyl glycolate (MG). A highly active and stable catalyst for the hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate (DMO) to methyl glycolate (MG) had been developed. The Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalysts were prepared by impregnation method with boric acid (H3BO3). The properties and the structures of the catalysts were fully characterized by BET, XRD, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, FTIR, XPS and TEM. Compared with Ag/SiO2 catalyst, the Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst exhibited significantly enhanced catalytic performance and high stability for the hydrogenation of DMO to MG under relatively milder reaction conditions (180°C, 0.5MPa). A high yield of 96.1% for MG was achieved over Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst, while the yield of MG was only 54.3% over Ag/SiO2 catalyst. The excellent catalytic performance for Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst was attributed to the introduction of B2O3. The addition of B2O3 to Ag/SiO2 catalyst favored the formation of highly dispersed Ag centers with electron-deficient state, which can strongly bind and activate the ester and acyl groups of DMO in the hydrogenation processes. Besides its effectiveness, the catalyst showed an excellent stability which can be performed for 264h under the reaction conditions of 180°C, 0.5MPa H2 and the weight space velocity of 0.2h−1. Keywords Dimethyl oxalate Methyl glycolate Hydrogenation Boron oxide 1 Introduction With the decreasing in crude oil resources, coal and natural gas will be of great significance substitutes for petroleum feedstock [1]. Among these resources, C1 chemical (e.g. syngas) research is attractive as its development meets the challenging environmental needs and industrialization requirements. The hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate (DMO) obtained from syngas to methyl glycolate (MG) is one of the vitally important applications for the C1 chemical. Methyl glycolate (MG) is an essential intermediate for the synthesis of pharmaceutical products, fine chemicals, and perfumes [2]. Recently, several approaches have been reported to synthesize MG including the carboxylation of formaldehyde and the hydrogenation of methyl formate. However, a major drawback associated with these methods is the severe reaction conditions or lower yields (<70%), which greatly lowers their potential in practical application [2–5]. By contrast, chemoselective gas-phase hydrogenation of DMO to corresponding MG is more attractive as it is a more economical and ecofriendly route compared with its synthesis from formaldehyde and methyl formate. Three main products could be obtained from the tandem hydrogenation of DMO. Typically, the partial hydrogenation of DMO to MG, then hydrogenation of MG to EG, and last the hydrogenolysis of EG to ethanol (EtOH) (as seen in Scheme 1 ) [6,7]. Many metal catalysts have been developed to catalyze the hydrogenation of DMO, including non-noble metal and noble metal. Among these non-noble catalysts, copper-based catalysts show capability in catalyzing the hydrogenation of DMO [8–15]. However, the yield of MG on the Cu based catalyst is extremely low at low temperatures as the low conversion of DMO. High temperatures (>200°C) were required to obtain high conversion of DMO. Nevertheless, high temperature was usually preferred for efficiently synthesizing the product of EG and EtOH as the thermodynamic constant of the second hydrogenation step is larger than that of the first hydrogenation step [6,16], leading to the low selectivity of MG. The MG would be the main products only when the conversion of DMO is below 70% over Cu-based [12]. In our previous study, we observed that a yield of 82% for MG could be achieved over Ni based catalyst under the reaction conditions of 210°C, 3MPa H2 and the weight space velocity of 0.1h−1 [7]. Ideally, it is desired for a chemical reaction with a product yield close to 100% as the separation of product from the reaction medium would be simple and easy in such case. It is hence that the design of a proper and high efficient catalyst to regulate the synthesis of the target products is desirable but more challengeable for both academia and industry interest. As the primary hydrogenation product, a moderate reaction condition and a catalyst with relatively weak hydrogenolysis capability is required for the synthesis of MG from DMO. Based on these understandings, many efforts pay much attention on noble metal catalyst such as silver based catalysts. For example, Yin et al. demonstrated that a high yield (>92%) of MG could be achieved over the 15 Ag/SiO2 and 10 Ag/MCM-41 catalysts under 220°C and 2.5MPa H2 [6,16]. Zheng et al. [17] reported that 4.5Ag/SBA catalyst could catalyze the DMO hydrogenation to MG with a high yield of 95.6% under 235°C and 3MPa H2. In order to further enhance the yield of MG, an Ag/CNT catalyst was developed for the hydrogenation of DMO to MG. The results indicated that a confined Ag nanomaterial in the channels of herringbone multi-walled carbon nanotubes (10Ag-in/hCNT) could effectively catalyze the hydrogenation of DMO, a yield of MG was 97% at 220°C and the H2 pressure of 3MPa [18]. Recently, Ouyang et al. demonstrated that the three dimensional 15Ag/KCC-1 catalyst with a hierarchical fibrous framework displayed capability in the hydrogenation of DMO to MG, and a high yield of MG 97.8% was obtained under the reaction conditions of 200°C and 3MPa, with a lifespan of 120h [19]. It can be observed that a high yield of MG can be obtained over these Ag-based catalysts, nevertheless, a severe reaction condition (above 200°C and 3MPa H2) was needed for the high activity of the catalyst. Additionally, the complexity in the synthesis of catalyst and the challenges in the catalyst stability lower the potential of these Ag-based catalysts in commercial applications. It is thus that developing an Ag-based catalyst with desirable catalytic efficiency under milder conditions, long-term stability, and easy handling is still a challenge [20]. A general consensus is that the catalytic performance and the stability of a metal catalyst can be significantly improved by incorporating an effective promoter (metal or metal oxide) as the enhanced dispersion of active metal and interaction between metal and dopant. Zheng et al. [17] reported that the addition of Ag to the catalyst of Au/SBA-15 significantly enhanced its catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of DMO to MG under 418K. However, the requirement of the noble metal Au limited its further application in industry. Recently, many studies have shown that B2O3 was a promising candidate for its sintering-resistant property and suitable acidity [10,21]. For instance, a B2O3-modified Ni/SiO2 catalyst with high metal dispersion and suitable acidity was verified to be effective for the hydrogenation of ethylbenzene as the strong interaction between surface nickel and boron species [21]. Zhu et al. [22] claimed that addition of suitable B2O3 to Cu/SiO2 catalyst pronouncedly enhanced the activity, 1,2-PDO selectivity, and stability for glycerol hydrogenolysis. However, up to now, the performance structure correlation of B2O3-doped Ag/SiO2 catalyst in comparison to the B2O3-free catalyst has scarcely been reported for the vapor phase selective hydrogenation of DMO to MG. Based on the above understandings, a highly active and stable Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst for hydrogenation of DMO to MG was developed in this work. A high yield of 96.1% for MG was achieved at 180°C and 0.5MPa. The attained yield values of MG over Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst are about 2 times of those over Ag/SiO2 catalyst under the identical reaction conditions. The influence of boron doping on the structure, acid-base properties, and active species of the catalysts was investigated deeply. Besides its effectiveness, the Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst displayed an excellent stability compared with the Ag/SiO2 catalyst in the hydrogenation process. It can be performed for more than 264h without deactivation at 180°C and 0.5MPa H2. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation SiO2 (Qingdao Ocean Chemical Co., Ltd., China) was used as the support for the catalysts. AgNO3 (AR) and H3BO3 (AR) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. and used as the starting materials. All the catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method. Typical procedures for the preparation of Ag/SiO2 and Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalysts were as follows. The Ag/SiO2 catalyst was prepared by impregnation of SiO2 support with an aqueous solution of AgNO3. The impregnated sample was dried overnight at 110°C and then calcined at 500°C in static air for 4h. The B2O3-modified Ag/SiO2 catalyst was prepared by the similar incipient wetness impregnation with aqueous solutions containing the desired amount of AgNO3 and H3BO3. The nominal weight loading of Ag and B were fixed at 10wt.% and 5wt.%, respectively for each catalysts, the Ag/SiO2 and Ag-B2O3/SiO2 standard for 10%Ag/SiO2 and 10%Ag-5%B2O3/SiO2, respectively. As comparison, the 5%Ag/SiO2, 12%Ag/SiO2, 10%Ag-2%B2O3/SiO2, 10%Ag-6%B2O3/SiO2 were prepared and the results were shown in the supporting information. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The surface area and pore volume of the catalysts measured by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, which were measured at −196°C by a Micromeritics ASAP 2420 instrument. The FTIR spectra of the catalysts were conducted on a Vertex 70(Bruker) FT-IR spectrophotometer with a deuterium triglycine sulfate (DTGS) detector. The powder samples were mixed with KBr (2wt.%) and pressed into translucent disks at room temperature. The in situ Methyl acetate-FTIR was collected on the same infrared spectrometer with the FTIR. Prior to the tests, the catalysts were reduced in situ at 300°C for 2h and then cooled to 30°C. Methyl acetate vapor was pulled through the chamber by a vacuum pump for the measurement and the spectra were recorded. After that, Methyl acetate-FTIR spectra were again recorded after applying a vacuum at different temperatures. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded with a D2/max-RA X-ray diffractometer (Bruker, Germany) operating with Cu Kα radiation at 30kV and 10mA over a 2θ range of 10° to 90° at a scanning speed of 2°/min. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) profiles were measured on Auto Chem.II2920 equipment (Mircromeritics, USA). Typically, 0.2g catalyst was pretreated in Ar at 150°C for 60min and then cooled to room temperature. Subsequently, the Ar flow was switched to 5% H2-Ar mixed gas and the sample was heated to 600°C at a ramping rate of 5°C/min. The H2 consumption was monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Temperature programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) experiments were conducted on the same apparatus as TPR. Prior to the adsorption of NH3, the catalyst (0.35g) was pretreated in H2 at 300°C to remove the adsorbed species for 1h. After cooling to 50°C, the catalyst was saturated with pure NH3 for 30min and then purged with He to remove the physical adsorption of NH3 for 30min. Subsequently, the sample was heated to 750°C with a rate of 10°C/min. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) measurement was performed with a JEM-1011 electron microscope operating at an 80kV voltage. The samples were dispersed in ethanol with an ultrasonic for 40min, and then the samples were fixed on copper grids coated with amorphous carbon films. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on a VGMiltiLab 2000 spectrometer with Mg Kα radiation and a multichannel detector. Prior to each test, the sample was reduced in a quartz tube at 300°C for 3h in 1atm H2. The obtained binding energies were calibrated using the C1s peak at 284.6eV as the reference. The experiment error was given within ±0.1eV. 2.3 Catalytic test The catalytic performance evaluation was performed over a fixed-bed reactor (diameter 12mm, length 600mm). Typically, 3g catalyst (20–40mesh) was packed into the stainless steel tubular reactor between two layers of quartz sand. Prior to test, catalyst was activated at 300°C for 3h in flowing H2 (100mlmin−1). After cooling to the reaction temperature, 15wt.% DMO in methanol and H2 were fed into the reactor at a H2/DMO molar ratio of 150 and the system pressure of 0.5MPa. The liquid products were determined by a gas chromatography (GC, Agilent 7890A, USA) equipped with an AB-INNOWAX capillary column (30m×0.32mm×0.5μm) and a flame ionization detector. The obtained products were also identified by GC-MS (6890N, Agilent, USA). The conversion of dimethyl oxalate and selectivity of products were calculated based on the following equations: C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = m o l e s o f D M O ( i n ) − m o l e s o f D M O ( o u t ) m o l e s o f D M O ( i n ) S e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = m o l e s o f one product m o l e s o f a l l p r o d u c t s 3 Results 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts 3.1.1 Physicochemical properties of the catalysts Table 1 summarizes the textural properties derived from N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the support of SiO2, Ag/SiO2 and B2O3-doped Ag/SiO2 catalysts. As listed in Table 1, SiO2 exhibits the largest BET surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter among the various catalysts. Apparently, the incorporation of Ag species significantly impacts on the physical properties of the samples, as notable decreases in BET surface area and pore volume are observed. This result reflected that the Ag species have successfully entered the pores of the supports. And then the surface area and pore volume was decreased as the blockage of pore by silver species [19]. Moreover, it can be observed that the BET surface area and pore volume were further decreased with the introduction of B2O3 to the catalyst of Ag/SiO2, indicating that partial of B2O3 was entered to the pores of the supports except for the Ag species, which was accordance with the previous reports [13,22]. Moreover, the isotherms of the SiO2 support, Ag/SiO2, Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalysts were also provided in the supporting information (Fig.S1). As shown in Fig.S1, both the support of SiO2, the Ag/SiO2 and Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalysts exhibit Langmuir type IV isotherms, which are the characteristic of mesostructured materials, illustrating that the Ag, B2O3 species and the preparation process do not change the structure of the support. 3.1.2 Structural properties of the catalysts The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectra of these calcined samples were carried out to verify the incorporation of B2O3 to the catalyst of Ag/SiO2 (as shown in Fig. 1 ). In the spectrum of Ag-B2O3/SiO2, the bands at around 677cm−1, 925cm−1 and 1420cm−1 were attributed to BOB bending vibrations, the stretching vibrations of BO bonds in BO4 units from diborate groups, and the BOstretching vibrations of trigonal (BO3) units in different borate groups, respectively [23,24]. These results provide the direct evidence for the efficient introduction of B2O3 to Ag/SiO2 catalyst. In addition, other three characteristic bands which centered at 1110, 800, and 470cm−1 were ascribed to the various vibration modes of Si-O bonds in the amorphous SiO2 for the catalyst of Ag/SiO2 and Ag-B2O3/SiO2 [25]. The XRD patterns of the Ag/SiO2 and Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalysts after the calcination at 500°C are displayed in Fig. 2 A. As shown in Fig. 2, both of the catalysts showed a broad peak at 22.5° ascribed to amorphous SiO2 [25]. The diffraction peaks at 2θ of 38.2°, 44.3°, 64.5° and 77.4° assigned to lattice planes of the Ag species were detected obviously for the Ag/SiO2 catalyst (JCPDS 65-2871) [16], indicating the low dispersion and the large particle size of Ag on the sheet of SiO2. However, no diffraction peaks of Ag species were observed for the Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst. Two weak peaks positioned at 2θ=14.6, 27.8 assigned to lattice planes of B2O3 were obtained [13] (JCPDS 06-0297). Additionally, the XRD results for the 10%Ag-2%B2O3/SiO2 and 10%Ag-6%B2O3/SiO2 were shown in the supporting information(Fig.S2), and no diffraction peaks of Ag species were detected. These results implied that the proper addition of B2O3 significantly promote the dispersion of Ag species and decrease their particle sizes. After reduction at 300°C under H2 atmosphere, the four sharp diffraction peaks positioned at 2θ of 38.2°, 44.3°, 64.5° and 77.4° ascribed to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) lattice planes of the metallic Ag appeared for the Ag/SiO2 catalyst [25]. Nevertheless, only a diffuse and broad peak centered at 2θ of 38.2° ascribed to the (111) lattice plane of Ag was observed for the Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst as the introduction of B2O3. Because of the weak interaction between silver species and silica support, the silver particles are favored to mobilize and aggregate to yield larger particles during the calcination and reduction process. In strong contrast, the incorporation of B2O3 was capable of controlling the growth of Ag particle size upon heat treatment, leading to the improved dispersion of Ag species. This result was in line with the result of XRD. As seen in Table 1, the average Ag particle size calculated by Scherrer equation declined gradually from 20.0nm for Ag/SiO2 to 7.34nm for Ag-B2O3/SiO2. TEM images were performed to further understand the dispersion and the morphology of the catalysts. Fig. 3 shows the typical TEM and HRTEM images of the reduced Ag/SiO2 and Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalysts. The black particles were assigned to the Ag NPs, which was verified by the HRTEM analysis. As illustrated in Fig. 3(A3 and B3), the crystal domains within Ag NPs had an interfringe distance of 0.21nm and 0.24nm, which are close to the lattice spacing of the (111) plane and the (200) plane in face-centred cubic (fcc) Ag crystal, respectively [17]. TEM images exhibit that the Ag nanoparticles (NPs) for Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst are smaller and more uniform than those on Ag/SiO2 catalyst. (Fig. 2A1 and B1).From the corresponding size distribution histogram of Ag NPs (Fig. 2C and D), it can be observed that the Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst has a super small average size of 7.37nm, while a large average size of 18.4nm was obtained for Ag/SiO2 catalyst, although the surface area of Ag/SiO2 was larger than the Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst. This result further indicated that the introduction of B2O3 could suppress the growth of Ag NPs and promote the dispersion of Ag species on the support of SiO2, which is consistent with the XRD results in Fig. 2B. XPS were performed to determine the surface composition and chemical state of reduced catalysts. The XPS patterns of the reduced Ag/SiO2 and Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalysts were presented in Fig. 4 . As shown in Fig. 4A, the Ag 3d XPS spectra of Ag/SiO2 sample displayed two strong and distinct peaks at around 368.15eV and 374.1eV attributed to the metallic peaks of Ag 3d5/2 and Ag 3d3/2, respectively [26]. However, a positive shift of 0.20–0.35eV for Ag 3d XPS signal was obtained in Ag-B2O3/SiO2 compared with the Ag 3d XPS of Ag/SiO2 catalyst, indicating that the active metal site of Ag was in electron-deficient state (Agδ+, 0<δ<1). Additionally, a negative shift of 0.20eV for B1s XPS signal (Fig. 4B) was observed in Ag-B2O3/SiO2 compared with the B1s XPS of B2O3. This phenomenon is presumed to be induced by a strong interaction between Ag species and boric oxide. Typically, the electronegativity of Ag and B is 1.93 and 2.04, respectively, i.e., B species has a relatively high affinity for electrons. It is hence deducedthat the electron might transfer from Ag to B, leading to the formation of Agδ+(0<δ<1) species, which is accordance with the previous reports [10,13,22]. The Ag with electron-deficient state owns the properties of Lewis acid, which could be of great importance for the absorption and activation of acyl groups in the hydrogenation process [7,10]. 3.1.3 Reducibility and surface acidic properties In order to explore the reduction behavior of these catalysts, the H2-TPR technique was performed. As displayed in Fig. 5 , the unmodified Ag/SiO2 catalyst presented a sharp symmetric reduction peak centered at about 75°C, which was attributed to the reduction of the well-dispersed AgO on the support of SiO2 to Ag0 [15,20]. However, it can be observed that the reduction peak of Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst shifted toward higher temperature (200°C) with the addition of B2O3, probably due to the strong chemical interaction between the basic silver oxide and the acidic boric oxide. The NH3-TPD characterization was carried out to evaluate the strength and quantity of acid on Ag/SiO2 and Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalysts and the obtained profiles are shown in Fig. 6 . It was observed that a broad peak centered at 150°C assigned to weak acid sites, was appeared over Ag/SiO2 catalyst surface. Compared with the Ag/SiO2 catalyst, the peak temperature increased gradually with the introduction of boron for Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst. Additionally, the peak area of the NH3 desorption of Ag-B2O3/SiO2 (Table 1, 22.20×10−2 mmolNH3/gcat.) catalyst was much higher than that of the Ag/SiO2 (Table 1, 7.54×10−2 mmol NH3/gcat.) catalyst. It is hence inferred that the addition of boron species not only increased acid amount but also enhanced acid strength, which was in well agreement with the previous reports [21,22,27]. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the catalysts The catalytic performance of Ag/SiO2 and Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalysts was tested in a continuous fixed-bed reactor using methanol as solvent, and the results are listed in Table 2 . For Ag/SiO2 catalyst, the conversion of DMO and the selectivity of MG were 1.7% and 97.3% respectively at 150°C. With increasing the temperature from 150°C to 200°C, the conversion of DMO increased from 1.7% to 98.1% with a selectivity of 97.4% to MG. Moreover, it can be found that the catalytic performance was enhanced significantly as the introduction of B2O3 into Ag/SiO2 catalyst. The conversion of DMO improved greatly from 6.7% to 98.9% with a 97.2% selectivity of MG as the reaction temperature increased from 150°C to 180°C. The Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst shows such considerable activity at 180°C and 0.5MPa H2, which is, to date, the best result in the literature concerning Ag-based catalysts [6,16,20]. As comparison, the catalysts with different Ag or B2O3 loadings, including 5%Ag/SiO2, 12%Ag/SiO2, 10%Ag-2%B2O3/SiO2, 10%Ag-6%B2O3/SiO2, were synthesized and the catalytic performances were tested in the supporting information (Table S1). It can be observed that the conversion of DMO was 12.6% over the catalyst of 5%Ag/SiO2, which was lower than that of over 10%Ag/SiO2 (54.4%). Nevertheless, with increasing the loading of Ag from 10% to 12%, the conversion of DMO was slightly changed from 54.4% to 57.9%. It is thus that the loading of Ag with 10% was the optimal choice considering the activity and economic efficiency. Moreover, it can be found that the introduction of B2O3 with 2% to 10%Ag/SiO2 can greatly enhance its activity for the hydrogenation of DMO to MG. The conversion of DMO was increased from 54.4% (over 10%Ag/SiO2) to 69.8% (over 10%Ag-2%B2O3/SiO2) under the identical reaction conditions. However, with increasing the content of B2O3 from 5% to 6%, the conversion of DMO was decreased from 98.9% to 75.9% as the excess B might cover some of Ag active sites. This indicated that the presence of B2O3 with suitable content is important for improving the catalytic efficiency since it can promote the dispersion of Ag active sites. Furthermore, it can modulate the electronic sate of Ag active sites, leading to the active metal site of Ag was in electron-deficient state, which was favorable to the hydrogenation of acyl groups in DMO. Additionally, the generation of dehydration product EtOH might be resulted from the weak acid sites of the Ag/SiO2 and the Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 6), which was also reported in the previous work [22,28]. To further understand the origin higher activity of Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst, the activation behaviors of CO bond on Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst were characterized by in situ Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR). Methyl acetate was chosen as the probe molecular, and the FT-IR spectra were recorded under 180°C. For methyl acetate, the peak appearing at 1760cm−1 region is ascribed to CO stretching vibration (Fig.S5a) [29]. A red shift in the wavenumber of CO stretching vibration peak occurred in two Ag-based catalysts. Interestingly, the red shift for Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst (40cm−1 Fig. S5b) is larger than that for Ag/SiO2 (28cm−1 Fig. S5c). The red shift of CO bond can be interpreted as the weakness in the strength of CO bond. This result confirms apparently that the activation of CO bonds are more effective on Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst than Ag/SiO2. Besides the high activity, the stability of the catalyst was crucial for DMO hydrogenation in the practical application. The long-term performance of representative Ag/SiO2 and Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalysts was conducted to research the stability of the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 7 , a negligible changing of MG yield was observed with Ag-B2O3/SiO2 as the catalyst after performance for 264h. However, a serious deactivation for the Ag/SiO2 catalyst was obtained at the identical reaction conditions. The yield of MG decreased from 52.3% to 28.5% after 264h running. Furthermore, a comparison of the TEM image and the XRD profile of the spent catalysts with that of the fresh ones suggested that the Ag NPs size was slightly increased for the Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst, while the Ag NPs size increased from 18.4nm to 30nm for the Ag/SiO2 catalyst (See Fig.S1 and Fig.S2). These results reflect the high stability and reusability of the Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst. The high stability of the Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst can be ascribed to the strong interaction between Ag species and B2O3, which was confirmed by the characterization of XPS (Fig. 4) and H2-TPR(Fig. 5). 4 Discussions 4.1 Influence of boron on catalyst activities Silver-based catalyst was widely used in catalytic oxidation reaction, such as ethylene epoxidation and methanol oxidation to formaldehyde [30–35]. Recently, lots of reports revealed that silver-based catalyst was also an potential catalyst in several hydrogenation reaction, including hydrogenation of unsaturated aldehydes (acrolein, crotonaldehyde) [36,37], citral [38,39] and ester. For example, some reports confirmed that silver-based catalyst show ability in catalyzing the hydrogenation of DMO to MG [6,16]. However, the severe reaction conditions were required to obtain a high yield of MG. It is thus that the catalytic performance of Ag-based catalyst was still need to be improved. Many research reported that modifying catalysts with boron is one of the most effective ways to improve the catalytic performance of catalysts. The incorporation of boron could affect the dispersion and the electronic structure of the active metal. In the present work, a catalyst of Ag- B2O3/SiO2 prepared by the impregnate method with boric oxide was developed, and it was verified to be highly efficiency for the hydrogenation of DMO to MG. Under relative milder reaction conditions, the B2O3-free Ag/SiO2 catalyst exhibited low catalytic activity, while the Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst displayed significantly enhanced activity. The superior hydrogenation activity of Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst was attributed to the introduction of B2O3, which facilitate the dispersion of Ag NPs on the surface of SiO2. As shown in Figs. 1 and 3(C and D), the Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst has an excellent dispersion and super small average size of Ag NPs. The size of the Ag NPs for Ag-B2O3/SiO2 was around one third of those for Ag/SiO2 catalyst. Many studies demonstrated that the active metal with smaller size are more active than larger ones in the hydrogenation of CO group [40–43]. Moreover, XPS characterizations corroborated that the active metal of Ag sites in the Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst was in electron-deficient state with the properties of Lewis acid, which can promote the activation of oxygen atom of CO group, then enhancing the hydrogenation catalytic efficiency. This was also confirmed by the in-situ FTIR with methyl acetate as the probe molecular (Fig.S5). Additionally, because of the active metal of Ag with a small positive charge (the electron acceptor), the adsorption of Ag sites to CO (the electron donor) groups in DMO can be promoted (Fig.S5b). 4.2 Influence of boron on catalyst stability It is crucial for the catalyst with a long-term stability in gas-phase hydrogenation of DMO from the practical viewpoint. Tan et al. proposed that the addition of boron could improve the stability of Co-based catalyst by selectively blocking the deposition, nucleation, and growth of resilient carbon species on its surface under conditions Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [44]. He et al. [10] reported that the enhanced stability for Cu-B/SiO2 catalysts was ascribed to the addition of boron species, which can block the growth of copper particles during the high-temperature heat treatment. Moreover, the electronegativity of boron element (2.0) was higher than that of silicon (1.8), leading to a stronger interaction of copper with boric oxide than with silicon oxide. The strong interaction plays an important role in suppressing the surface migration of copper nanoparticles, stabilizing the metal nanoparticles and leading to an excellent catalytic stability. On the basis of the literature and our results, the stability of Ag/SiO2 catalyst prepared by simple impregnate method was poor as the weak interaction between the active metal and support. In contrast, because of the strong interaction between the active metal Ag and B species, the Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst, displayed an excellent stability in the hydrogenation of DMO to MG. As revealed by TPR measurement, the reduction peaks of Ag species in Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst presented a gradual shift to a higher temperature compared with the Ag/SiO2 catalyst. The shift of the reduction peak could be ascribed to the strong interaction between Ag species and B2O3. In addition, the XPS result indicated that the Ag 3d5/2 peak of the Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst shifted to relatively higher binding energy values in comparison with the Ag/SiO2 catalyst, while a negative shift of 0.2eV for B XPS signal was observed in Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst compared with the B 1s of B2O3. This result also implied the occurrence of an interaction between the active metal of Ag and B species. As a result, the fine dispersion of Ag nanoparticles on the support of SiO2, the electron-deficient state of Ag sites and the strong interaction between Ag and B species were the essence reasons for the Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst with an excellent stability and extremely high activity in the hydrogenation of DMO to MG. 5 Conclusions In conclusion, the addition of B2O3 to Ag/SiO2 catalyst plays an important role in enhancing the catalytic activity and stability for Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst in hydrogenation of DMO to MG. An increase in dispersion of Ag species, a decrease in Ag nanoparticle size and Ag sites with electron-deficient state were observed when a suitable amount of boron was introduced into the catalyst, leading to an excellent catalytic performance for Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst. A 98.9% conversion of DMO together with a MG selectivity of 97.2% can be achieved at 180°C and 0.5MPa H2. Besides its high catalytic efficiency, the Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst exhibited superior long-term performance, which was mainly related to the strong interaction between Ag and boron species and the stabilizing effect of B2O3 on Ag nanoparticles. coredata.dc:description: A highly active and stable catalyst for the hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate (DMO) to methyl glycolate (MG) had been developed. The Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalysts were prepared by impregnation method with boric acid (H3BO3). The properties and the structures of the catalysts were fully characterized by BET, XRD, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, FTIR, XPS and TEM. Compared with Ag/SiO2 catalyst, the Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst exhibited significantly enhanced catalytic performance and high stability for the hydrogenation of DMO to MG under relatively milder reaction conditions (180°C, 0.5MPa). A high yield of 96.1% for MG was achieved over Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst, while the yield of MG was only 54.3% over Ag/SiO2 catalyst. The excellent catalytic performance for Ag-B2O3/SiO2 catalyst was attributed to the introduction of B2O3. The addition of B2O3 to Ag/SiO2 catalyst favored the formation of highly dispersed Ag centers with electron-deficient state, which can strongly bind and activate the ester and acyl groups of DMO in the hydrogenation processes. Besides its effectiveness, the catalyst showed an excellent stability which can be performed for 264h under the reaction conditions of 180°C, 0.5MPa H2 and the weight space velocity of 0.2h−1.
coredata.dc:title: Promoting effect of boron oxide on Ag/SiO2 catalyst for the hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate to methyl glycolate
